awd_titl_txt: Improving Scientific Writing In Undergraduate STEM Classrooms: A Training Program for Students and Teaching Assistants Aided By Information Extraction Technology
awd_abstract_narration:
Scientific thinking and communication skills are vital for 21st century STEM careers. Research indicates that cycles of writing drafts, receiving actionable feedback and coaching, then making further refinements until a final product emerges is the most effective way for students to develop these skills. Ideally, students should be writing and revising routinely, but this may be time- and labor-intensive to be practical in high-enrollment STEM courses. Also, college teachers may not know how best to make high-impact writing instruction part of their classes. This project uses a research-based curriculum designed to develop scientific reasoning skills through writing, combining text analysis technology with an integrated writing training program.  The project will test whether students' writing skills development can be accelerated by combining reading and text annotation exercises, automated feedback using text analysis technology, and holistic feedback from instructors. Graduate teaching assistants' mastery of these training methods will also be examined. Finally, the project will look directly at technology impacts by measuring how much automated feedback students use, and how that translates into progress towards writing mastery.

The project's goal is to improve scientific writing skills of undergraduate students by promoting adoption of evidence-based writing training. The project has three interacting elements. 1) STEM Automated Writing Help Tool (SAWHET) is a computer-based tool designed to teach undergraduates scientific writing according to best practice principles. SAWHET collects texts of draft student lab reports, conducts text analysis, then gives students tailored feedback. 2) The Biology Thesis Assessment Protocol (BioTAP) is a protocol for assessing undergraduate STEM research theses. BioTAP will be used to teach students to score published papers and training reports before writing their first report. 3) Graduate teaching assistants will be trained to teach and assess scientific writing more consistently. The central research question will be addressed: Can an integrated writing training program combining these three elements accelerate student writing skills development? Assessments will include standardized student and teaching assistant knowledge, self-efficacy, and experience surveys; videotape analysis of classroom instruction; lexical complexity modeling of student writing; qualitative analysis of instructor comments on reports, and student lab evaluations. This project will provide much-needed data on how technology support affects development of scientific writing skills. Project products will include a repository of approximately 4,000 annotated biology student lab reports that can be used as training data for linguistic analyses, to test other automated systems, and other research.

por.por_cntn:
Our goal for this project was to build, test, and share an evidence-based strategy for college faculty to teach scientific writing in high-enrollment introductory STEM courses. 

Why teach writing in STEM classes?

Good communication skills are essential for 21st century STEM workers. Jobs skills aside, scientific writing helps students learn to state problems, present claims, then summarize evidence and reasoning to support those claims. Regular practice & individualized feedback builds critical and applied thinking skills that help students evaluate personal choices, social issues, and policies connected to science and technology. Unfortunately, most students don't get enough opportunities to practice scientific writing. Most STEM teachers have not been trained to teach scientific writing. Also, BIO100 courses often have dozens or hundreds of students, which makes it hard for teachers to give individualized feedback. 

We designed and tested a Six Elements Method (SEM) (see Figure 1) for teaching scientific writing in large, multi-section introductory biology (and other STEM) courses. SEM combines research and proven practices from the Writing Across the Curriculum/ Writing in Disciplines (WAC/WID) field, over a decade of local observations, and NSF-supported research.

SEM brings together:

  • Guidelines that help students understand the "why", not just the "how" of writing;
  • Student and instructor training activities that show exactly how scientific writing is organized;
  • Diagnostic activities that tell teachers where students need more help;
  • Automated support that helps students avoid common errors, and teachers spend less time grading;
  • Bins-based grading, which is fairer and more informative; and
  • Feedback as reflective coaching, not copy editing. 

What did we learn from this project?

Training and diagnostic exercises benefit students and teachers both. Students averaged 11% fewer basic organizational errors in their writing. Errors in these exercises predicted which mistakes students were most likely to make when they wrote full-length reports. Instructors could use results from the exercises to decide which areas to focus on most. 

Web-based report collection and automated pre-grading feedback & analysis reduced the number of incomplete reports submitted from 36% to 5.5% in just 1 year. 

Average course grades were 4-12% higher overall after adopting bins scoring. Instructors also graded more consistently; variation between courses dropped from 6-12% historically, to 3-4%. 

Instructors could grade reports faster. Grading time dropped from 30-60 minutes/report to 12 minutes for initial submissions (range = 5-32 min.) and 6 minutes for revision versions (range = 4-13 min.)

Less experienced instructors still prefer to copy edit students' writing. We plan to look at instructor resistance to using reflective coaching further.

Bins scoring reduced student complaints about grading on end of course evaluations from 46.7% to 17.9% of comments. First-year students agreed that it is fair and logical. Students in their 3rd or 4th year reported that SEM prepared them well for writing in other courses, and gave them confidence in their ability to write clearly in professional situations.

SEM helps students gain basic scientific writing skills faster. Using computer-based text analysis, we found:

  • Total number of unique words used rose 25.1%; academic & specialized vocabulary grew faster (24.2-38.1%) than use of general terms (12.1%-17.8%), meaning students were using a more ?formal? vocabulary.
  • Word repetition declined 11.4-20.6%, meaning students were writing more concisely.
  • Readability indices that measured frequency of long or polysyllabic words rose 10.3-41.9%, meaning students were composing more complex sentences.

What are the broader impacts of this project?

We now know it is possible to automate and streamline scientific writing training so that it:

  • better matches best practices of professional writing instructors; and
  • can fit into high-enrollment introductory biology courses.

All project resources are available from our website on the BioQUEST /QUBES Hub (see Figure 2) or from linked GitHub repositories. We already have been sharing our SEM strategy for teaching scientific writing through national-level faculty training workshops, in-person and video presentations, and published articles.

We hope to recruit more faculty to test individual elements of SEM, or even better, adopt the full model. Given that writing is a barrier to success in STEM (especially for under-represented groups) we hope that broader adoption of SEM can help to make STEM courses and careers accessible for more students. 

Accessing Our Resources

Go to BioQUEST/QUBES Hub  to read about how SEM works, or download Creative Commons-licensed student and instructor resources. Instructors can download our Biology Writing Resource Guide in multiple formats then modify to fit their specific needs. Others may want to use our R Shiny web form for collecting and pre-screening reports, or our data archive of >4400 student reports.
